item.title: Critical Role: The Almost Impossible (Campaign 1 - Vox Machina)
item.description: This is a repost of a previous project originally from 15 June 2024. 1. Introduction Critical Role is a series in which a star-studded cast of Hollywood voice actors play Dungeons & Dragons. It’s a story known for its length (and you thought catching up on the Marvel Cinematic Universe was bad): Critical Role Run Time in Context Campaign Start Date End Date Play Time # of 45' Cable TV Episodes 1 - Vox Machina March 2015 October 2017 373 hours 23 minutes 497.

item.title: Rower Hometown Map - pt.1
item.description: Introduction An important part of building a continually successful rowing team - or any team with turnover for that matter - is strategic recruitment. If you don’t have high quality people coming in as your previous high quality people leave, you’re going to be in a tough spot. Many Division 1 teams in the United States recruit from all across the country and internationally to find the talent that will help their team continue their storied legacy of excellence.

item.title: Bao Dough
item.description: by B Ingredients Yields 1 batch Ingredient Amount Water ~Body Temperature 236 g Yeast 6 g Flour 381 g Cornstarch 78 g Sugar 70 g Salt 12 g Pork fat OR Butter 2 Tbsp Preparation Add yeast to the water - let stand until foamy. Mix flour, cornstarch, sugar, and salt in the stand mixer bowl. Add the water mixture and mix until a cohesive ball forms. Once the ball is formed, add the pork fat a little bit at a time until it is all added.

item.title: Chinese BBQ Pork
item.description: by B Ingredients Yields ~1-3 lbs Ingredient Amount Pork shoulder, cut into slabs 1-3 lbs Brown Sugar 3 Tbsp Honey 3 Tbsp Chinese 5-Spice 1.5 tsp Shaoxing Rice Wine 2 Tbsp Soy Sauce 1 Tbsp Hoisin Sauce 2 Tbsp (+1 if no Bean Curd) Red or Black Bean Curd 1 Tbsp Sesame Oil 1 Tbsp Salt 2 Tbsp Preparation Mix brown sugar, 5-spice, shaoxing rice wine, soy sauce, hoisin sauce, bean curd, sesame oil, and sea salt together in a bowl.

item.title: Zaatar Bread
item.description: by Fresh Corner Market (University of Oregon) Ingredients 4 Tbsp Zaatar Spice Blend Ingredient Amount Thyme to taste (?) Toasted Sesame Seeds to taste (?) Sumac to taste (?) Coarse Salt to taste (?) Assembly Ingredient Amount Small Naan Bread 40 Olive Oil 1/4 Cup Toasted Sesame Seeds 1/2 Cup Preparation Mix your zaatar blend. Brush naan with olive oil and sprinkle generously with zaatar bread. Sprinkle toasted sesame seeds on the bread.

item.title: Learning Neovim (pt. 1)
item.description: Sidestepping the Roadblock… While attempting to work through Git BASH yesterday to get this site set up, I got Trapped in Vimâ„¢, which is apparently a very normal experience for beginners: After trying what felt like everything that made sense and caving in to my impatience in the moment, I closed the window and learned how to change the default editor in Git Bash and set it to nano: git config --global core.

item.title: Fig Balsamic Dressing
item.description: by Fresh Corner Market (University of Oregon) Ingredients Yields 2 Cups Ingredient Amount Soaked Black Mission Figs 10 Balsamic Vinegar 1/3 Cup Olive Oil 1 Cup Black Pepper 1/2 tsp Salt 1 tsp Lemon Juice 1 tsp Dijon Mustard 1 Tbsp Preparation Pre-soak Black Mission Figs in 1 cup of water for 2 hours, then reserve the water for later. Blend all ingredients until smooth, starting slow and adding reserved water if necessary.

item.title: New live test
item.description: We made it! If you’re reading this, it means that the site is live. As a beginner, I ran into many challenges that will likely give my later self a good laugh. Adding the .nojekyll file and adding the “publishDir: docs” line to the config.yaml seem to have done the trick in getting this live. Now that it’s live, I need to test updating the content. My first attempt will be the following steps:

item.title: SQL: Zero to Advanced pt. 1
item.description: materials by Bosscoder Academy, found on LinkedIn Format The materials are sorted into 24 “days” of learning, each with a central theme. My goal is to break them into 3 posts, 8 “days” each, with a distillation of the already brief material in each section as a review of SQL. 1. Introduction to SQL and Relational Databases 1.1 Content SELECT - INSERT - UPDATE - DELETE - 1.2 Practice Questions Question Answer Write a SQL query to insert a new record into the "

item.title: About
item.description: Recent Realizations At the time of writing I’m only a little more than 4 months into coding, but I’m learning a lot quickly. I started with a one-day, six-hour workshop with the University of Oregon data services department covering basic R in late March. The skills I learned in that workshop served as the foundation for data processing that amplified my primary career. From there I learned to make a basic website to showcase a resume and basic portfolio pieces.

item.title: "The Arboreal Repository"
item.description: Recent Realizations I’m only 3 months into coding, but I’m learning a lot quickly R resume website then linux commands accidentally then SQL then Python out of need blogdown website Title Meaning Repository - a safe place to store and retrieve information arboreal - like a tree, I’m not perfect and am going to make mistakes and not do things perfectly. better to log while I’m going through it and not in hind-site.

item.title: Hello R Markdown
item.description: R Markdown This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com. You can embed an R code chunk like this: summary(cars) ## speed dist ## Min. : 4.0 Min. : 2.00 ## 1st Qu.:12.0 1st Qu.: 26.00 ## Median :15.0 Median : 36.00 ## Mean :15.4 Mean : 42.98 ## 3rd Qu.

item.title: A Plain Markdown Post
item.description: This is a post written in plain Markdown (*.md) instead of R Markdown (*.Rmd). The major differences are: You cannot run any R code in a plain Markdown document, whereas in an R Markdown document, you can embed R code chunks (```{r}); A plain Markdown post is rendered through Blackfriday, and an R Markdown document is compiled by rmarkdown and Pandoc. There are many differences in syntax between Blackfriday’s Markdown and Pandoc’s Markdown.
